answerText: Tlaloc[10] The primary Aztec water goddess is the jade-skirted Chalchiuhtlicue, whose son Tecciztecatl represents this heavenly body. Other deities associated with this object include the Akkadian Sin, the Finnish Kuu, and the Greek Selene.
heading: ACF Regionals |2013 | Yale A + Minnesota A | 3 | Mythology | None | College
subject: Mythology
question: Question: If you're traveling to classical Mesoamerica, don't drink the water Â– there's all sorts of mythical crap in it. For 10 points each: [10] Don't die in the water either, or you'll end up in this Aztec storm god's special underworld with midgets and victims of water-borne disease. Along with Huitzilopochtli, this fanged god had a pyramid at the Templo Mayor.
